definitions.definition: to move your tongue over the surface of something in order to taste it, make it wet or clean it

examples.text: The cat sat licking its paws.

definitions.definition: to eat or drink something by licking it

examples.text: The cat licked up the milk.
She licked the honey off the spoon.
Flames were soon licking the curtains.
The flames were now licking at their feet.

definitions.definition: to easily defeat somebody or deal with something

examples.text: It was a tricky problem but I think we've licked it.

definitions.definition: to train somebody so that they do a particular job, task, etc. well

examples.text: It took him just two weeks to knock the new recruits into shape.

definitions.definition: to show too much respect for somebody in authority because you want to please them
to train somebody so that they do a particular job, task, etc. well

examples.text: Leave the boy with me—I'll soon lick him into shape!

definitions.definition: to move your tongue over your lips, especially before eating something good
to show that you are excited about something and want it to happen soon

examples.text: They were licking their lips at the thought of clinching the deal.

definitions.definition: to spend time trying to get your strength or confidence back after a defeat or a disappointing experience

examples.text: Leeds are still licking their wounds after their humiliating defeat by Grimsby.

wordOrigin: Old English liccian, of West Germanic origin; related to Dutch likken and German lecken, from an Indo-European root shared by Greek leikhein and Latin lingere.
